awd_abstract_narration:
Combinatorics is a central branch of mathematics concerned with the description and analysis of discrete data structures. Combinatorialists try to uncover patterns and building blocks in such structures, in order to explain their global behavior. Combinatorial tools are therefore of central importance in many other fields of science, such as computer science, statistical mechanics, statistics, and probability. This project focuses on the encoding of several discrete geometrical structures (planar graphs, polytopal decompositions of space, etc.) by simpler mathematical structures. Such an encoding, which provides a genuinely different description of the same structures, can greatly simplify the analysis of the objects under consideration. Indeed, certain patterns and probabilistic behavior which were hidden in the original description, may appear more clearly in the alternative description.

This projects aims to develop bijective tools in order to solve several fundamental open problems in combinatorics, with motivations coming from probability, theoretical physics, and computer science. One of the major goals is to set the foundation for a multi-authored proof of a deep relation between three very important probabilistic constructions: random planar graphs, the Gaussian free field, and SLE curves. The proof will be built upon a bijective encoding of percolation-endowed planar triangulations by some two-dimensional lattice walks. Other goals of this project are related to proper coloring of graphs (explaining bijectively a counting formula for properly colored planar graphs), integrable system approach to the symmetric group ("diagonalizing" the KP differential equations governing the factorizations in the symmetric group), hyperplane arrangements (bijections for the faces of the deformations of the Coxeter arrangement), and graph drawing algorithms (simultaneous generalization of Schnyder woods and transversal structures).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The PI has used bijective techniques to solve several mathematical problems. These problems have connections with several fields of research: combinatorics (in particular graph theory and enumerative combinatorics), statistical mechanics, probability, and computer science. 


A major goal accomplished by the PI is to set the foundation for a (multi-authored) proof of a deep relation between two models of random surfaces. The first model of random surface is ``random triangulations'': roughly speaking the random network obtained by gluing a lot of small triangles together at random (but planarly). The second notion of random surface is ``Liouville quantum gravity'', which is a random density in the plane closely related to the Gaussian Free Field. Both of these models have been heavily studied in probability and mathematical physics (and both were proposed as describing the space-time evolution of strings).With his coauthors, the PI has shown that conformally-embedded random triangulations converge to Liouville quantum gravity, thereby showing that these two models of random geometry are closely related. An additional result is that the interfaces of the site-percolation model on random triangulations  converge to the random curves known as Schramm Loewner Evolutions. In order to achieve this goal, the PI has used a bijection between percolation-endowed triangulations and certain lattice walks in the quarter plane. 

Some other achievements of the PI under this proposal are listed below:

- Extending the theory of the Tutte polynomial (a fundamental and well-studied graph invariant) to the setting of polymatroids, and showing that the Tutte polynomial is a polynomial function of the values of the rank function. 

- Extending classical reciprocity results for the chromatic polynomial of graphs in terms of acyclic orientations

- Generalizing and unifying the notion of Schnyder woods and regular edge-labeling (which are fundamental tools for the design of graph-drawing algorithms) to larger classes of planar graphs.

- Enumerating faces in the decomposition of space induced by hyperplane arrangements which are of the braid type.

In terms of broader impacts, the project has contributed to the development of human capital in several ways.The PI has mentored three PhD students at Brandeis (Duncan Levear, Changxin Ding and Shizhe Liang) on subjects related to this proposal.The PI has supervised two MIT-PRIMES projects (initiation of high-school students to mathematical research) as part of the NSF support: one during the year 2019 and one during the year 2020.

The PI has disseminated his finding through research articles (freely available on the arXiv website), and has given many seminars and conferences. In particular the PI gave an invited plenary address at the AMS Sectional Meeting held in Hartford Connecticut in April 2019, and a minicourse at the workshop ``Random maps and matrices from a geometric perspective'' held at Ecole Normale Superieure de Lyon in May 2019. The PI was member of the program committee of the FPSAC conference 2019. The PI has made his articles, presentation slides, presentation recordings, and computation worksheets available on his website. The PI's work (collaboration with Gregory Miermont and Nicolas Curien) was featured in the  article ``Random surfaces hide an intricate order'' of the broad-audience journal Quanta Magazine, and in a subsequent podcast.
